Detection of new domain user account cre.Action: Monitor Windows Event ID 4720 on Domain Controllers. Correlate creation events with authorized change management requests or administrator activity logs. Identify account creation events occurring outside of scheduled maintenance windows or associated with unknown user/process contexts. Compare rate of account creation against historical baseline (time series analysis) to detect anomalies.

Identification of recently created domai.Data: Windows Event ID 4720; Windows Event ID 4728; Windows Event ID 4732; Windows Event ID 4733; Windows Event ID 4624; Zeek conn.log
Identification of recently created domai.Action: Audit attributes of recently created accounts (Event ID 4720). Identify accounts with suspicious names (e.g., random strings, mimicking legitimate accounts). Check for immediate addition to privileged groups (Event ID 4728, 4732, 4733). Monitor login activity (Event ID 4624, Zeek conn.log) for these new accounts, looking for atypical login times, locations, or resource access patterns (descriptive statistics, correlation analysis with other activity).

Execution of domain account creation com.Action: Monitor Windows Event ID 4688 on Domain Controllers and critical servers for command-line arguments containing 'net user /add /domain'. Flag events where the creating process is not a known legitimate administrative tool or script, or if executed by a non-administrator account. Analyze frequency and timing of such command executions using time series analysis to detect unusual spikes.

Network connections or resource access o.Data: Windows Event ID 4624; Windows Event ID 4663; Zeek conn.log
Network connections or resource access o.Action: Correlate Windows Event ID 4720 (Account Creation) with subsequent Windows Event ID 4624 (Logon) and Windows Event ID 4663 (Object Access) events, as well as Zeek conn.log entries, attributed to the newly created account name within a short time window (e.g., 30-60 minutes) after creation. Identify connections or access attempts to sensitive data or systems not typically accessed by new accounts. Use descriptive statistics to characterize typical first-login activity for new accounts and flag deviations.
